presented the idea of a linear transformation of \RNr[n] as an operation which transforms \RNr[n] in such a way that lines get transformed into lines. We then discussed in detail the main types: Scaling operations, orthogonal projections and reflections, shear transformations, and rotations of the plane.

Here we deepen our understanding of linear transformations. This will then enable us to describe linear maps with prescribed transformation properties in arbitrary subvector spaces of \RNr[n]. Here are some examples

intro.para: These developments provide a platform for the following chapter on eigentheory. There we ask and answer the question: given a square matrix \Mtrx{A}, which transformation of space does it describe? We find that \Mtrx{A} is a product of matrices each of which describes a scaling operation, or a rotation, or a shear transformation.
